fn.p: ERP effects of contextual predictability can sometimes appear to begin before 300ms. It has been hypothesized that this earlier divergence may reflect a distinct ERP component from the N400 that is more sensitive to the effects of predicting phonological/orthographic properties of an incoming word (e.g. Lau, Holcomb & Kuperberg, 2013; Brothers, Swaab, & Traxler, 2015).

Late posterior positivities have been described in response to multiple different types of linguistic anomalies, including syntactic anomalies/dispreferred continuations, and the literature on this set of components comes from several different angles. In the present study, we focus on the late posterior positivity/P600 effect produced by semantic anomalies. While some of the ideas we propose are relevant to understanding the syntactic P600 (as well as posteriorly distributed late positivities that are evoked by other types of linguistic and non-linguistic violations), a full discussion of these relationships is outside the scope of this paper.

The mental model includes the comprehender’s situation model — a term that is often used in the discourse literature to refer to the comprehender’s understanding of the full set of events, actions, and characters described in a text (Van Dijk & Kintsch, 1983; Zwaan & Radvansky, 1998). Here we chose to use the more general term, mental model, to emphasize that this level of representation is also influenced by multiple types of non-linguistic information.

In the present study, the event structure was defined largely by the thematic properties of verb in the third sentence — properties that define the semantic roles around specific types of actions or states (Dowty, 1989; Gruber, 1965; Fillmore, 1967; Jackendoff, 1987). However, other types of linguistic cues can constrain for particular event structures, e.g. presupposition triggers (see Shetreet, Alexander, Romoli, Chierchia & Kuperberg, 2019) and concessive discourse connectives (see Xiang & Kuperberg, 2015).

We initially carried out statistical analyses on trial-averaged data within each of these spatiotemporal regions of interest. However, as a reviewer pointed out, this limits our ability to generalize our findings to new sets of items (see Clark, 1973). In linear mixed-effect regression models, items, like subjects, are treated as a random effect, allowing for generalization to different sets of items. The pattern of results from these regression analyses was the same as from our earlier trial-averaged subjects analyses. We also carried out an initial omnibus ANOVA analyses on the trial-averaged data, with Scenario Type (five levels corresponding to the five conditions) and Region (five levels corresponding to five regions across the anterior-posterior distribution of the scalp) as within-subjects variables. These analyses confirmed that both the N400 and the late positivity effects differed significantly across the five conditions in their scalp distribution (significant Scenario Type by Region interactions in both the 300-500ms and the 600-1000ms time windows, Fs > 9.66, ps < .0001).

Similar to previous findings (Paczynski & Kuperberg, 2011), the degree of N400 modulation depended on whether the verb constrained for an animate or inanimate direct object, and on the animacy of the argument. A detailed discussion of these interactions is beyond the scope of the current paper.

Generative models are classically described within Bayesian probabilistic frameworks of cognition (Griffiths, Kemp & Tenenbaum, 2008) at Marr’s first computational level of analysis. However, they can also be instantiated at Marr’s second algorithmic level (see McClelland 1998 & 2013).

A generative framework also assumes that, at least under some circumstances, the comprehender can predict/pre-activate information at other levels of representation. In the present study, this would include other lexical properties associated with the upcoming critical word. Specifically, in both high constraint and low constraint contexts, she is likely to have predicted its syntactic representation (a noun-phrase). And, in the high constraint contexts, she may have also predicted its phonological/orthographic representation (swimmers).

Although the late frontal positivity effect evoked by the low constraint unexpected (versus high constraint expected) critical words was not significant, examination of the voltage map for this contrast (shown in Figure 6) suggests that the spatial distribution of this effect was qualitatively similar to the distribution of the effect observed when contrasting high constraint unexpected and high constraint expected critical words within this time window.

Note that the term ‘integration’ in relation to the N400 has not always been used to imply combinatorial processing. It has sometimes been used simply to refer to a delayed (‘post-lexical’) use of context to facilitate semantic processing of incoming words, without assumptions about whether this includes combinatorial processes that build new propositional meaning (e.g. Chwilla, Hagoort & Brown, 1998; Van Petten & Luka, 2012).

We also note here that this interpretation of the late posterior positivity/P600 differs from a previous account that has linked this component more generally to the overall degree of “integration difficulty” (Brouwer, Fitz & Hoeks, 2012). Under the present model, the role of impossibility, and any functional distinctions between the late frontal and posterior positivity are not discussed.

Coherence monitoring is thought to be an important component of successful reading comprehension, see Garner, 1980; Wagoner, 1983, Cain, 2016. While it is well established that the late posterior positivity/P600 is largest when participants are explicitly asked to make coherence judgments (e.g., Xiang & Kuperberg, 2015; Kolk et al., 2003), as discussed by Kuperberg, 2007, section 3.5, page 33, such judgments are neither necessary nor sufficient to produce the effect.
